item.title: Recognition and Observation
item.description: Many years ago, in my little book of quotes, I connected two thoughts by Charles Péguy and Michel Foucault, both dedicated to observation: You must always say what you see: but above all, and it is more difficult, you must always see what you see. Charles Péguy (Radio France) Curiosity is a vice that has been stigmatized by Christianity, philosophy, and even by a certain conception of science. Curiosity, frivolity. Yet, I like the word; it evokes care; it evokes the attention we give to what exists (…) ; a certain determination to break free from our familiarities and to look at the same things differently (…).

item.title: A Scary Judge of Talent
About Observation
item.description: The sense of observation is rarely mentioned as a factor of success in our personal or professional lives. The video below corrects this injustice in less than 90 seconds. Published on LinkedIn1, this video is accompanied by comments praising various qualities of coach BriAnna Garza: her humility when she apologizes for not acting sooner, her pedagogical sense when she remains silent after a missed shot, or her enthusiasm when she shouts to the player that he is a true shooter.
